Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Johna Leddy at University of Iowa and her group will explore improved catalysis at electrodes irradiated with ultrasound. Classically, rates of chemical reactions increase with temperature and pressure. On irradiation of solutions with ultrasound, large localized excursions of temperature and pressure can be achieved. In a thin layer electrochemical cell, these energetic excursions are captured at electrode surfaces and dramatically increase rates of otherwise slow electrochemical events. That thin layer sonoelectrochemistry is effective is demonstrated with preliminary data for several reactions of fundamental and technological importance. Because the energetic tax to drive ultrasonic transducers is low, sonication in a thin solvent layer may provide a general means to increase surface reaction rates.

The global objectives of this project are to identify the fundamental mechanisms by which thin layer sonoelectrochemistry increases interfacial rates; to map dependencies on acoustic frequency and intensity; to optimize system design for maximum capture of acoustic energy; and to explore mechanisms and materials where thin layer sonoelectrochemistry most effectively accelerates electrocatalysis. Thin layer sonoelectrocatalysis is a potentially transformative concept in the fundamentals of heterogeneous catalysis and in electrochemical energy technologies such as batteries and fuel cells. The intellectual merits of the proposal include a new and potentially transformative means to facilitate heterogeneous reactions that include electrocatalysis and a research approach that couples experiments and models to identify the fundamental processes that drive enhanced interfacial rates ultrasonically. The broader impacts include improved electrochemical energy technologies, tools to make measurements, and well trained STEM researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many advanced energy technologies rely on electrochemistry and efficient reactions at electrodes. This includes fuel cells, batteries, photovoltaics, and many electrosynthetic processes for materials. The energy generated or consumed in these technologies is often limited by the rate of reaction at the electrode surface. Increased rates correspond to increased efficiency. For batteries, fuel cells and photovoltaics, that corresponds to greater usable energy. Catalyst increase reaction rates and efficiency. Electrocatalysis is the process whereby an electrochemical reaction is made more efficient.

In this project, ultrasound is used to increase otherwise slow reactions. Ultrasound is high-frequency energy, where the frequencies are above the audible range of humans and most mammals. When a fluid is irradiated with ultrasound, cavitation is often observed. In cavitation, the energy waves of ultrasound compress and rarefy the fluid to form small voids or bubbles. When the bubbles collapse, a small zone between the void and fluid yields excursions of temperature and pressure. The temperatures are 5000 C and 1000 atm,  which corresponds to temperatures of the sun and pressures at the bottom of the ocean. Chemical rates are increased by temperature and pressure. Electrochemical systems typically place and electrode in a fluid, the electrolyte. Our experiments are designed to capture excursions in temperature and pressure generated by ultrasound at the electrode fluid interface. By capture of the energy at the interface, reaction rates are increased.

In our ultrasonic experiments, we activate electrocatalytic processes in a thin electrolyte layer where cavitation is not obvious. In this geometry, bubbles are not observed and reactions that are already rapid at the electrode surface are not affected. But reactions that are inherently slow and need an electrocatalyst are markedly increased in rate. The reactions we have examined are all critical in electrochemical energy systems of fuel cells and some batteries. Fuel cells are run on a fuel such as hydrogen and an alcohol such as methanol. To complete the circuit of an electrochemical energy system, oxygen is fed to the other electrode, often from air. In fuel cells, the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is the slow step in a hydrogen fuel cell. In a methanol fuel cell, where methanol is fed directly to the anode,  methanol oxidation that is the slow step, in part because of  byproducts deposited on the electrode, which include carbon monoxide. Our studies of ultrasonic effects on electrode reactions have shown increased rates for oxygen reduction (ORR), methanol electrolysis and oxidation, carbon monoxide oxidation, and hydrogen storage. The efficiencies of all of these processes are critical in advanced electrochemical energy storage and generation. They are especially important in portable power. We have also observed effects dependent on the solvent used in an electrochemical cell. Work continues to identify the fundamental impacts of ultrasound on interfacial electrode reactions, because fundamental understanding of these processes promotes basic science and provides a platform to improve important energy technologies.

In a broader view, the studies at electrode surfaces can be expanded to other heterogeneous catalytic systems where a solid catalyst is in contact with a fluid. The studies in a thin fluid layer at an interface impact broader domains of science and engineering because this configuration avoids obvious cavitation that can otherwise degrade the solid surface. A novel, low energy means to increase rates can be exploited in disciplines beyond electrochemistry. Interestingly, the oscillators used to irradiate surfaces are piezoelectric materials, typically driven by applied voltages but little or no current flow so that power and energy consumption, and so cost, is minimal for substantial increases in rate. Under this grant, broader impacts are provided by student training that includes several undergraduates and graduate students. During the grant, four doctoral students completed degrees in chemistry and math with specialization in electrochemistry. Three of these students are now assistant professors in US universities, training the next generation of students in the electrochemistry that is important in advanced energy technologies.
